div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: SATURDAY, September 30, 1905. CHILDREN OF THE DISPERSION.
div.p: The correspondance published in the "Times” between Mr. Lucien Wolf and Mr. Israel Zangwill on Jewish colonisation contains many points to excite the imagination end rouse the interest of all who have sympathy with the race, heroic, patient, brilliant end steadfast, to which they both belong. The two patriots reach an agreement to forward the scheme for the establishment of a Jewish autonomous state in the waste lands of the British Empire from precisely opposite standpoints Mr. Zangwill is among those who "remember Jerusalem in their mirth,” and look to the reestablishment of the Chosen People as a nation upon the Hill of Zion, Mr. Wolf not only does not see the smallest indica tion that events are moving in the direction of making such a return possible, but does not desire that it should be so. The time is past, he says, for the Jewish race to be uni-national; he looks rather to see his people good citizens of the countries of their adoption. Perhaps his ideal is not less patriotic than Mr Zangwills. For social reasons, however, and chiefly to ease the congestion within the Jewish pale of Russia, Mr. Wolf is ready to join the Jewish Territorial Organisation in its endeavour to plant a colony in any favorable region of the British Empire where a grant may be obtained. The new State is to be developed along the line of a self-governing British Colony, the gover nor or administrator to be a Jew, but the most thorough religions tolerance to be exercised When British folk can only supply twelve millions of white inhabitants to their posse sions overseas, the offer to colonies a great tract of land with an industrious and thrift; population is one not to be lightly refused Mr. Zangwill announces that not only the poor and persecuted Jew of the lower orders is prepared to cast in his lot with his co-religion ex ists in East Africa, but also middle-class Jews some of them men of considerable so bet ana The prospect of success is greatly enhanced thereby. Like all other countries, the new Stet will undoubtedly at the outset be pastoral an agricultural To many this will, perhapa suggest a doubt of its probable prosperity The modern Jew is chiefly successful a financier, merchant, or tradesman. But of ok he was an agriculturist; and that his capacity for working the land has not passed away may be seen from certain communities is Southern Russia, where in the early part of last century Jewish families were planted on the soil and kept there at the point of the bayonet until today their descendants are among the most prosperous of Russian farmers. In process of time industries may take root in the proposed ed colony, as Mr. Zangwill hopes No doubt a tract of country with mineral renames will be sought with this and in view.

We trust that the British Government will see its way to making such a grant of land that the colony may have a fair prospect of success. Whether we believe or disbelieving that the gorgeous promise of prophecy, "the ransomed of the Lord shall return and com to Zion, with songs end everlasting joy upon their heads," presages an actual return of the afflicted people to the Holy City, we cannot refuse to acknowledge that, despite ever attempt to destroy it, the racial spirit of the Jews is unbroken today, as it was when the legions of Titos stormed and sacked the Temple. If it be the of Great Britain to promote the reunion of the Children of the Dispersion behind the power of the Britain Navy, Great Britain may wall ha proud of her destiny. Whether it be the direct inte position of the Divine Hand, or the working of natural law, the prediction of Balaam over Israel appears to hold good today: "Blessed is be that bleseeth thee, and cursed is that ourseth thee." No nation has pros pen among wheat pence otic a of the Jews have bean a feature of national policy.

div.head: ENGLAND AND RUSSIA. PROPOSED ENTENTE.
div.p: Moscow, September 39. Count Lambsdorff has declared to an English notability that the Tsar and himself wish for an agreement between Russia and England. (Havas

div.head: AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY. REVISION LAW OP 1867.
div.p: Vienna, September 30. M. de GauUch announced in the Reichsrath that the Government proposes that the re- spective Parliaments of Austria and Hungary appoint deputations to meet in the spring to discuss the revision law of 1867, regulating the joint affairs of the two countries. He is convinced,that such a revision would benefit both countries and Monarchy as a whole. (Reuter)

div.head: SUGAR COMPANY FAILURE. A DEPRESSED PARIS MARKET.
div.p: Paris, September 29. The market here is depressed owing to the the failure of an important sugar company. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MANILA TYPHOON.
div.p: Manila, September 29. Eleven Americans and twenty-four natives were drowned in the sinking of a gunboat during the typhoon. (Reuter)

div.head: THE LATE COUNT DE BRAZZA.
div.p: Marseilles, September 29. The mortal remains of Count de Brazza have arrived. ( Havas)

div.head: THE NEW LORD MAYOR.
div.p: London, September 29. Alderman Walter Vaughan Morgan has been elected Lord Mayor. (Reuter)

Mr. Walter Vaughan Morgan, Lord Mayor elect of London, is a Welshman by birth and descent. He was born on May 8,1831, being the sixth son of Thomas Morgan of Glasbury, and Marianne, daughter of Mr.William Vaugh- an of Brecon. Educated at Christ's Hospital, he entered the service of the National Pro- vincial Bank ot England in 1846. In 1856 he retired as chief cashier of the Manchester branch, to join his brothers in London in founding the firm of Morgan Brothers, mer- chants and newspaper proprietors, and the Morgan Crucible Company ; the firm consisted of six brothers who continued in partnership for thirty years, and still so continue except that death has reduced their number to three.

The new Lord Mayor, who is one of the proprietors of the "Chemist and Druggist” and "The Ironmonger,” well-known trade journals, is a freemason of many years standing. He was Grand Treasurer of the Grand Lodge of Eng- land in 1897-98. After becoming an Alderman and Magistrate of the city of London, he was appointed Sheriff of the city in 1900-01, and is one of H.M.’s Lieutenants for the city. He is unmarried and a member of the Reform and Gresham Clubs.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Jewish Festival —To-day being the Hebrew New Year’s day many of the Jewish business houses are closed.
Want of Space compels us to hold over the less important news which we have received until our next issue.
Quarantine. A telegram from Pera an- nounces that arrivals from Aden will be subjected to a medical visit.
The Greek Colony.— To-day being the name day of the Crown Princess Sophia of Greece, thanksgiving services were held at the Greek Orthodox Churches of Alexandria.

Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Co.— The sportsman’s train on the Aboukir line will be suppressed from Monday next, and train No. 17 will resume its ordinary service, the last departure from Aboukir being at 9 p.m.

The Alhambra Theatre.—The manage- ment of this theatre announced a matinée for to-morrow when La Dame de chez Maxim will be staged. Monday evening’s performance, for which Fourchambault is billed, will be devoted to the benefit of Signor A. Maggi.

The Brindisi Mail will be made up at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence. Registered letters must be handed in not later than 9 p m. on Sunday, and insured articles, money orders, and parcels, by noon on the latter day.

Suez Canal.—16 vessels passed through the canal on the 26th and 27th inst., previous to the temporary cessation of traffic, 6 of there were British, 5 German, 1 Dutch, 2 Italian, 2 French. The receipts for the two days were frs. 542,013 28, making the total from the 1st inst. (which is not likely to bé increased np to the end of September), frs. 7,798,405.25.

Coal Imports.—From the 1st of January to the 28th of September. 794,370 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 428,660, Newcastle 185,919. Scotland 98.112, Yorkshire 52,686 and other places 29,953 tons. During the same period last year 765,539 tons were received. This is the first time that the return has shown an increase of the import of coal daring the present year as compared with 1904.

Akhmin Greek Catholics.—Our Akhmin correspondent writes that the Patriarch Hiro- los of the Greek Catholic Church paid a visit to that town on the 25th inst. He came from Girgeh by steamer, and was met at the wharf by a large crowd of people, who accompanied him to the church and listened with interest to his solemn address. His Beatitude spent two days at Akhmin, where he visited many families, and then left for Sohag.

A Few Facts. — The first Berlitz School was established in May, 1878. There are now 235 branches all over the world. Among the students have been members of the Royal families of England, Spain and Germany, of Presidents of the United States, of the French Republic, as well as Ambassadors, Ministers, Senators, Professors of the leading Universities, and famous writers. The Berlitz Method has received the highest awards at all International Exhibitions, and its prin- ciples were adopted by the Congress of Modern Languages, Paris, 1900.

Fatal Fire at Gabbari.—At 5 a.m. today a fire broke out in the upper story of a house in the Gabbari quarter. The fire bri- gade sent off an engine at once on being called up, and were engaged in putting out the flames whom the occupant of the house, a merchant named Abd el Rahim Hassan, threw himself from a window without waiting or a fire escape or ladder to be put up and received such severe injuries that he expired while being conveyed to hospital. The flames were quickly extinguished, and an enquiry as to the origin of the fire and the amount of damage done, is proceeding.

San Stefano Casino.— Yesterday after- noon's entertainment at the San Stefano Casino in aid of the sufferers from the recent earth- quakes in Calabria was an immense success. Amongst those present we noticed H.E. Khalil Hamdi Pasha Hamada, the committee and a large number of members of the San Stefano Club, Baron Acton, Consul General of Italy, H.B. Fakhry Pasha, Mr. Webb, M. Scotidis, Hellenic Consul, Count Zizinia, and many others. The band of the Customs porters’ chil- dren played several elections in an admirable manner, and the dancing of Professor Longhi’s pupils was exceedingly well done and made a very pretty sight The Brachale orchestra gave several selections from Verdi's operas which were greatly appreciated, and at the conclusion of the performance the management of the Casino very kindly distributed a number of small presents amongst the children. The receipts of the fête amounted to £60, and as all the expenses were defrayed by the San Stefano Casino and H.E. Khalil Hamdi Pasha Hamada, the fall sum was handed over to Baron Acton for his Calabrian relief fund.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES. M. DE LA BOUGLISE'S DEATH
div.p: It appears that the late M. de la Bouglise was found lying dead in the Sharia Soliman Pasha by two Italians. He was evidently on his way back from the Villa Victoria where be had called upon M. Leroux, when the disease, from which he had long suffered, struck him down. The corpse was taken to the Abdin caracol, where it was identified by M. Bertrand and MM. Leronx and Naus.

The funeral, which left the French hospital at 4 p.m. yesterday, was attended by M. Bertrand and the French consular staff, by many members of the French colony, and the leading representatives of the Sucreries Com- pany. The body of the late M. de la Bouglise was interred in a vault in tho Old Cairo ceme- tery, pending instructions from the family of the deceased.
M. Leroux left Cairo for Europe yesterday, having received news of the serious illness of his mother. He hopes to return to Egypt in a short time.

div.head: THE PRINCES AND THE DAIRA.
div.p: We learn that the action brought by the Princes, sons of the late Khedive Ismail Pasha, against the Government for the restoration to them of the remaining surplus of the Daira Sanieh will come before the Cairo Mixed Courts on October 20.

div.head: SUICIDE OF A BRITISH SUBJECT.
div.p: A European, believed to be an Englishman resident in Ceylon, shot himself with a revolver at 8 p.m. yesterday on the beach near San Stefano. The deceased, whose name appears to be T. Peters, had come up to San Stefano from Alexandria for the afternoon We have thus far received no information as to the history of the deceased or the cause of his suicide, the results of the Consular inquest which opened at the Ras el Tin hospi- tal at midday not having reached us before we went to press.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENT COMPANY.
div.p: We published particulars in our issue of the 22nd instant of the now company that has just been formed, with Sir William Willcocks as chairman, and which will be brought out in the course of next month.

We are now informed that so favorably is this new undertaking viewed by both the European and the Native communities that already more than the entire capital of L B. 500,000 has been privately applied for, the applications coming in from all parts of the country, and ranging from five shares to several thousands. To comply with the rules of the local bourses a third of the share capital will, however, have to be offered for public sub- scription so as to obtain a quotation of the sharer of the company. Among the satisfactory points to be noted are the following. No pro- motion money will be paid in connection with the formation of the company but a certain number of founders' shares will be created,and these wilt be allotted to the promoters in lieu of payment in cash. The shareholders will moreover be entitled to a prior and cumulative yearly dividend of four per cent, and the founders’ shares only participate to the extent of thirty per cent of the surplus profits, the balance of seventy per cent going to the share- holders. In the meanwhile we may mention that the support the promoters have so far received greatly exceeds their most sanguine anti- cipations.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Indian Prince left Middlesborough yesterday and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about October 15th. The S.S. Cyprian Prince left London on Wednesday with general cargo and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about 14th October. The Russian Steam Navigation Company's S.S. Nachimoff will leave Alexandria on October 8 for Odessa, touching at Port Said, Jaffa, Beyrouth, Tripoli, Ohio, Smyrna, Dardanelles, and Constantinople, and will connect with the Black Sea service.
The Khédivial express mail steamship El Kahira will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Wednesday for Piraeos, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.
The S.S. City of Khios of the Papayanni Line left Malta yesterday evening and is ex- pected to arrive at Alexandria on Tuesday morning with mails and passengers.
The S.S. Assiout of the Westcott and Laurence Line left Malta yesterday and is due at Alexandria on Monday or Tuesday, with general cargo from London and a cargo of coals from Newcastle.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Cambridge arrived last night from Glasgow, Liverpool, and Malta with passengers and general cargo.
The Eilerman S.S. Avon sailed from Liver- pool yesterday with general cargo for Alex- andria direct.
The Westcott S.S. Egyptian sailed lest night for Odessa.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID. AFTER THE EXPLOSION. (From our Correspondent).
div.p: Port Said, Friday. The consequences of the explosion yesterday, notably the rapidly growing congestion of the harbour here,are beginning to make themselves apparent There are thirteen ships now on the buoys and vessels have been arriving steadily all day. The coal basin is to be utilised shortly for ships as they come in from sea and the Dutch, or man-of-war anchorage will be used for vessels of short' length. The big berths in front of the main streets, Rue de Commerce and Quai Eugenie, are reserved for the arrival of mail and passenger boats, in all, the har- bour, as it is at present can accommodate with cue about 25 more vessels, and this number will soon be reached, as a glance at the lists of ships due here will shew. There is talk of moving the vessels now in harbour into the canal between here and Ras el Bah,as the new arrivals make extra berthing space a necessity and I should think that this will require to be done in a few days, as early during next week several large passenger boats will arrive.

I have heard nothing of what arrangements are being made regarding the transport of mails in the event of the canal still blocked when the Brindisi boat comes in on Wednesday, but hopes have been expressed by competent authorities that it may be possible to send vessels through the canal past the Chatham’s remains by that time.
No strangers are allowed to go down the canal on any account, though frequent requests have been made by residents and others for permission to view the spot.

Work is being pushed on by night and day at kilometre 18.4 ; Arabs in hundreds are busily engaged removing débris from the canal banks, and redoing the chaos which reigned yesterday to some semblance of order and system. Fish is their staple food, and these continue to come to the surface in hundreds, porpoise, black fish, and mullet being the principal species.
The sounding charts are practically com- pleted, and a consultation is to be held the moment the soundings and examination of the state of the bottom of the canal are com- pleted.

Mr. Harris is to remain here to give the Canal Company the benefit of his knowledge in the matter of blowing up what remains of the now famous ship, and two divers who are skilled in submarine mining are due here to morrow to go on with what Mr. Harris suggests. It is probable that no new explosion will be made for a while, it it is found that dredging will make the channel clear enough to allow the accumulated ships to get through.
There are seventeen ships at Suez this afternoon but none are allowed to enter the canal.

div.head: (From Another Correspondent.)
div.p: Alexandria, September SO. As I passed the scene of the explosion on my return home yesterday, few traces were visible of the destruction caused by Thursday’s explosion. The train moved along slowly, thus enabling me easily to see all there was to be seen. All that could be discerned on the east or Asiatic bank was the gap caused by the explosion, and, at the distance from which we saw it, this did not appear to be very extensive.

All that was to be seen of the unfortunate Chatham was a portion of the mast in the water. Several dredgers were at work in the canal, and steam launches and other vessels in the service of the company were also busily employed. The fresh-water canal had no fish remaining on its surface, -this could hardly be expected twenty-six hours after the shock that had killed them. Probably at that time few remained uneaten. I cannot say that the inter of this canal looked very inviting,in fact that of the maritime canal looked far more fit for drinking purposes. It was perhaps as well that I did not notice this water before reaching Port Said, for although when filtered it was beautifully clear and palatable, its state as it flows between the banks most certainly appears to leave much to be desired. The western bank of the canal bears no traces whatever—apart from the pipes and other appliances used- of the explosion, and no one would imagine even that the telegraph wires had been interfered with. Nor did I see any broken glass about.

I had a short but interesting conversation with Captain Hill, of the Chatham, on Thurs- day. It is not, I think, generally known that the cause of the fire spreading so rapidly after the collision with the Clan Cumming was the foot that the lamp (or lamps) upset set fire to some highly flammable composition contain- ing naphtha, many drums of which were stored on board. These Exploded one after another, reusing the rapid extension of the fire which necessitated the flooding and consequent sinking of the vessel with its dangerous cargo. As to this same composition it is stated that but for a contravention of the law which abso- lutely prohibits the storing of such stuff in confined spaces, and insists upon the drums being carried on the open deck, free to the air, no serious results would have arisen from the slight collision which took place. Such colli- sions,I hear, are of somewhat frequent occurrence.

More work for the lawyers!! The gentlemen of the long robe will no doubt be extremely busy for a time, and the ill wind of the disaster will blow them at least much good in the shape of fees. In conversation with Mr, Hama yesterday, that gentleman informed me that it was probable that his stay in Egypt might be a somewhat prolonged one, as his evidence might be required in a pending notion respecting the dynamite which was exploded under his direction at Aboukir in Jane last Litigation ! litigation ! when will arbitration takes its place in the settle- ment of disputes? The question is easily answered. Never ! so long as the lawyers are the power they are at present, in every nation and in every clime. T. A.

We should like to state that the tele- gram received by our esteemed contempo- rary "La Reforme” from its special corres- pondent at Port Said, attributing to the "Egyptian Gazette” the statement that dyna- mite cartridges remained in the canal after the explosion, has no foundation whatever in fact.

div.head: NOTES FROM ASSIOUT. CRIME ON THE DESERT ROAD. (From our Correspondent.)
div.p: Assiout, September 24. . It may not be too late to communicate to you a few details of the crime committed on the road to the Oasis. As a matter of fact, the examination of the witnesses ended only re- cently, and it was useless to give details before ascertaining their truth.

The policeman, who returned to Assiout with the news of the crime, had sustained three wounds in the head and shoulders, but these proved later to have been self- inflicted. The reason for this self-mutilation was that he himself was the murderer, his anger having been aroused by the fact that his wife had been guilty of improper conduct with one of the camel drivers.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. the Khedive, who attended Friday’s prayers at the Montazsh mosque, will leave Montazah by a special train to-day to visit his Mariout estates.
Said Bay Shukair, director of accounts to the Sudan Administration, arrived with his family yesterday by the Messageries boat and proceeded to Cairo.
Milhem Shakoor Bey returned to Cairo from the Carlton Hotel, Ramleh, yesterday.
Sir Augustus Hemming, who will be accom- panied by Lady and Miss Hemming, will again winter in Egypt, leaving England at the end of October.
Our Hellenic contemporaries state that M. Pargalo, Judge of the Alexandria Misted Courts, intends to resign his functions.
Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy, Port Said, we notice : — Major L’Estrange John- stone, Lord Edward Cecil, Captain Roberts, Captain Walker, Charleton Bey, Mr. Wills, Dr. Hayward.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR. We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion THE CAIRO CITY POLICE.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—It appears to be the fashion "all the year round” for most people who know anything bad about the city police to im- mediately communicate it nicely trimmed to the local press, while those, if there be any, (and I think there must be one every now and then) who happen to know anything good about the members of the force seem always careful to keep it to themselves. I will ask you, if you think it worth while, to give your read- ers particulars of the following case, which I think, most of them will admit, reflects the greatest credit on the city police, as well as on the Parquet and on the present existing ma- chinery and its working, which enabled them to capture and bring the offender to trial in such a very short time.

On the 13th inst I reported to the Cairo city police that some handkerchiefs had been stolen from “An Dé Rouge.” Molazim Awal Ahmed Effendi Zeki of the Mouski police dis- trict commenced an investigation of the case, in such a keen, intelligent and effective man- ner, that in a very short time a man was arrested when offering the stolen handkerchiefs for sale in the Fagallah quarter, and another (a Sudan- ese) at the Cairo railway station. The police investigation threw suspicion on a Sudanese servant employed by me. He bolted, and although he lived near the Saida Bl Zeinab quarter, he was cleverly arrested by a native shawish of the city police, when hiding upstairs in a liquor shop off Clot Bey street.

To-day the three were brought to trial by the Parquet, and sent to prison with hard labour for six months, i.e. in 15 days from the time the theft was reported to the police. I am, Sir, etc. P. Plunkett Cairo, September 28.

div.head: SERPENT WORSHIP IN EGYPT
div.p: The last two numbers of the "Revue de l’Histoire des Religions" contain a remarks ble article by M. Aun-lineau, in which he labours to prove that the cosntant represen tation by the Egyptians of gods in serpent form implies the doctrine that the souls of the gods took refuge after death within the bodies of living snakes. This agrees fairly well with the facts noted by M. Maspero in his essay on “De Quelques Cultes et de Quelques Croyances Popalaires des Egyptians,” wherein be points oat that not only were certain deities — for instance, the goddess Miritskro -alluded to in terms which leave no doubt that they were actual and verita ble serpents, but also the snake is still rever enced among both Christians and Mahom- medans in Egypt at the present day. We have heard of houses in Alexandria and Cairo where a cobra is a sort of pensioner fed on birds and milk. That this should be so is by no means astonishing, when we consider how widespread is such worship throughout Africa so far south even as Dahomey. This should warn us against looking too exclusively to Asia as the source of Egyptian outturn. That M. Amelineau’s reasoning is conclusive can, however, hardly be said, and his writings continue to present that incapacity for clear statement which have gone far to render his really epoch-making work at Abydos of less value than it should have been. The chapters devoted to it in M. de Morgan’s "Les Origines de l’Egypte" still remain the only intelligible record of it yet published, and the perusal of of M. Amelineau’s four huge volumes on “Les Novelles Fouilles d’Abydos" leaves the reader more confused than before as to what he really discovered there. Yet his latest theory certainly demands careful consideration. The representations of serpents, both divine and demoniacal, on every page, not only in the "Book of the Dead,” but also in the other funeral texts known as the "Book of Hades," the "Book of the Gates," and the like, are suggestive, as is the representation-which be does not seem to have noticed—of (the Greek) Sarapis and Isis under the guise of crowned serpents, sometimes with human heads.

div.head: SIR C. PHIPPS AND THE CONGO TROUBLE.
div.p: Mr. E. D. Morel, of the Congo Reform Association, has sent the following letter to the Press :— The Congo Reform Association has been informed on official authority of the repudia- tion by Sir Constantine Phipps of the attitude attributed to him in connexion with Sir Albert Rollit’s speech at Liege on September 6 last.

The Association welcomes the announcement, and ventures to hope that some explanation will be forthcoming on the part of those who have made themselves responsible for the dis- semination throughout the world of information not consonant with fact.

It surely cannot have been a mere accident that Renter’s agent at Liege should have gone ont of his way to accentuate the circumstance now repudiated by Sir Constantine Phipps— that the applause which greeted Sir Albert Rollit’s remarkable statements "was led by the British Minister" ?

Nor is it easy to regard as fortuitous the circumstance that the fuller report of the Liege proceedings issued subsequently to Renter’s accoout of the same, by the manage- ment of the British section should have em- phasised that it was the Congo part of Sir Albert Rollit’s speech which was specially punctuated with applause, and that it was this applause "to which the British Minister gave the lead." In view of the capital which has Keen made out of the whole incident by the defenders, official and unofficial, of the Congo- lese regime in Europe, is it too much to expect that those concerned will feel it incumbent upon them to explain ?
The matter wants clearing up. Yours faithfully, B. D. Morel. Congo Reform Association, 4, Oldhall-street, Liverpool, September 18.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET Kearsley and Cunningham’s Weekly Report.
div.p: Liverpool, September 21, The market this week has been very quiet, the business being quite of a retail character, quotations,however,are unchanged. In Futures the business has also been very limited. The following are the latest values :— Sep. 7.42 Nov. 7.31 Jan. 7.18 , Oct. 7.38 Deo. 7.24 Feb. 7.17 Mar. 7.1C

American Futures. The market this week has been fairly active, and prices have fluctuated sharply, a decline of six points has been followed by an advance of 15@ 17 points. Todays closing values being 9 @11 pts. higher than those of last Thurs- day. The decline was chiefly due to the general belief in lower prices. and bear ma- nipulation, and the advance to the with- holding by the South of the actual cotton, and considerable covering operations by the short interest. Apparently at 50 @60 points decline the South withheld their cotton, and with the assistance of banks, conferences and combinations, they appear to possess the power to do so whenever prices fall or are driven below the basis they consider that they should obtain for their produce. They proved last season that they can largely control the price, and although present con- ditions are not so favorable to them, they evidently intend to use their power this season in the same direction.

The following are the latest quotations :— Sep. 5.57 Dec./Jan. 5.64 Apr./May 5.73 Sep./Oct 5.56 Jan./Feb. 5.67 May/June-6.73 Oct/Nov. 5.58 Feb./Mar. 5.69 June/July 5.74 Nov./Deo. 5.61 Mar./Apl. 5.71 July/Aug. 5.74

div.head: COTTON SETTLEMENT CELEBRATION.
div.p: To celebrate the recent settlement of the Lancashire cotton dispute, the Lord Mayor of Manchester entertained at dinner, on Wed- nesday, last week, the representatives of the employers and operatives who took part in the conference arranged at his invitation, as a re- sult of which the crisis was ended. The Lord Mayor presided, and in congratulating his guests on the happy ending to the dispute, he said that the settlement had been welcomed by all sections of the community. Among the letters he had received was one from the Prime Minister expressing his satisfaction.

Mr. C. W. Macara, President of the Master Cotton Spinners’ Association, in responding to the toast "prosperity to the Cotton Trade," said the forces of Capital, and Labour had join- ed in the movement to extend the growth of cotton throughout the British Empire, and to protect the interests of the cotton industry, and he expressed the hope that in the coming deliberations some means would be, equitable to all, by which disputes and differences might be expeditiously and amicably settled, found, without recourse to lock-outs and strikes.
The Lord Mayor received the thanks of the assembly for his kindly intervention in the dispute.

div.head: LONDON COMMERCIAL REPORT London, September 22.
div.p: Gum Arabic —Bombay descriptions keep very quiet, and few sales are reported. Sudan kinds are also quiet, but firmly held by im- porters ; moderate sales, however, have taken place at full values. Persian sorts have been fairly active, both on the spot and to arrive, at fall rates.
Gum Benjamin.—Of 21 cases 16 sold,medium Sumatra 3ads at 6/ to 6/ 10s, fair Palembang 2nd in time at 40.
Gum Euphorium.—66 packages withdrawn or bought in.
Gum Myrrh,—Of 18 packages 1 case sold, without reserve, partly blocky at 85s.

Gum Olibanum. - Of 114 packages 81 sold, including red drop badly garbled, subjects at 32s, slightly blocky garblings, without reserve, at 17s to 18s, 54 cases good garblings being sold privately,price not reported.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.
div.p: —We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appoint- ing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of XI. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain farther particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: MATTERS OF MOMENT. PITH OF THE PRESS COMMENTS. RUSSIA AND THE POLES. “Times.”
div.p: Whether they have grasped the full con- sequences of their plan or not, the Russian Committee of Ministers appear to have evolved a series of measures which will give a direct and considerable increase of strength to the Polish nationality from that fact we most conclude that they are not afraid, at present, ' of intrenching it in a more influential position | in the Empire. The actual concessions that will affect the Poles are comprised in two recent Imperial Ukases. One of them, the edict on religious toleration, applies indiffer- ently to the whole Empire. The other, which regulates teaching in the schools, the revival of representation of the nobles, and the acqui- sition of landed property in the nine “Western Governments,” relates to the Poles directly. The chief secret of Polish acquiescence in Russian rule is, we cannot doubt, that the Poles prefer to remain with the Slav rather than to court by any other policy the dangers of Teutonic aggression. The Russian Govern- ment will be well advised to make them loyal and contented subjects. Its new programme is welcome as tending to that result, even if it has been partially inspired by less creditable motives.

div.head: EGYPT AND MOROCCO. "Telegraph."
div.p: The "Novoye Viemya”— a journal represent- ing views not usually friendly to this country— while dismissing certain suggestions as inad- missible, by no means scouts the idea of an Anglo Russian entente. No responsible au- thority known to us has ever proposed that we should offer to Russia rights which are not ours to give away. In the Anglo French Con- vention there was no question of exchanging “rights" in Egypt for “rights” in Morocco. The contracting parties recognised the pre- dominant interests—quite another thing from rights—of one another in the respective coun- tries of Egypt and Morocco, and undertook not to interfere with the protection and devel- opment of these interests, subject always to respect for the legitimate interests of other Powers. No British statesman could possibly "offer" Constantinople to Russia, or the re- version of the Sick Man’s inheritance in Asia Minor, for the good and sufficient reason that they are not ours to give or to withhold. It is, however, a different thing to say that Eng- land has ceased to have the peculiar interest in the Near Bast which was the mainspring of our traditional policy in the Palmeratonian days.- Our relations with the Mediterranean Powers, the opening of the Sues Canal, and many other developments have changed all that.”

div.head: IN MACEDONIA. "The Morning Post." .
div.p: During the past three weeks the Ambassa- dors of the powers have been uncommonly constant in their attendance at the Selamlik, and have been received in audience both by the Sultan and tie Minister for Foreign Affaire so frequently as to excite some comment. The Russian Ambassador has his own axe to grind. His business is to impress the Sultan with the idea that the emotion of forts on the Bosphorus is an unkind if not an unfriendly act towards benevolent Russia . . . . The root-cause of the of the present disturbances is that Bulgaria and Greece both sea that their chances of possessing Macedonia are fading in proportion as the police become more efficient and influen- tial In fact, this view of the matter is being frankly advanced by a section of the Bulgarian Press, and therefore the assumption can hardly be wrong that financial control is not the only subject which the Sultan has to discuss with the Ambassadors to his Court

div.head: LIBERAL CRITICISM OF CHINESE LABOUR. "Daily News."
div.p: From the carefully phrased report of Lord Solborue’s meeting with the Boer farmers yes- terday, we might imagine that everything in the Transvaal was "working smoothly and satisfactorily,” as the Archbishops would say. The Boers apparently only needed a few com- forting words from the High Commissioner to realise their happy position and the “inevit- ableness” of Chinese labour, and to buret out into "a round of hearty cheers.” The report does credit *o the discretion of the reporter and the affability of Lord Selborne as well as to the unexacting nature of the Boers. It is difficult to find the reason for their com- plaisance in the facts...............

Only this week it has been necessary to amend the Ordinance, with a view to inducing tha civilian population to help the polios in recapturing the runaways. And if the means of protection are sufficient, why arm the Boers Bat, indeed, there is no need to ask this ques- tion in face of the accumulated facts of the escapes and criminal incidents which can no longer be concealed. Something like a reign of terrorism is developing, and the sinister admission was made by the President of the Chamber of Mines yesterday that there was no power of preventing the police from leaving the compounds.”

div.head: “Westminster Gazette."
div.p: Lord Selborne declared that the Chinese "scare" would soon be over, but we see that Mr. Chaplin, the President of the Chamber of Mines, declared that the mining companies are "unable, under the Ordinance, to restrict the compounds." If they were permitted to do so, it would be moat undesirable, as it would mean condemning the coolies to an existence which might be called slavery thus giving rise to disturbances and depriving them of the power of spending practically the whole of their wages in the country, which power they at present possess.

We are rather inclined to agree that the compound should not be a prison ; but at the same time we feel sure that the inhabitants of the Transvaal never contemplated a state of facts in which the Chinese woe Id be able so easily to get at large.

div.head: MOROCCAN NEGOTIATIONS. The "Journal” (Paris).
div.p: The negotiations concerning Morocco did not advance a step yesterday Neither the date nor the place of the conference has yet been fixed. Germany wishes the conference to be held at Tangier, and M. Revoil refuses to agree to this.

div.head: "Le Matin."
div.p: The conversations which Dr. Rosen, M. Rouvier, and M. Revoil bad yesterday were very protracted and very important. Once more M. Rouvier will have to settle difficulties which people seem to wish to complicate as they please. He will have to furnish replies to demands which it was not thought would arise again. Meanwhile, the opinion is gaining ground in certain circles of the public that if the negotiations should become the complicated, M. Rouvier would suggest having the diffe rences settled by a court of arbitration,such as the Hague.

div.head: “Liberal."
div.p: The “Liberal” argues that Spain has the same right to demand guarantees on the Moorish frontier as France. A large sum has already been expended at Melilla on the sup- port of Moorish fugitives, and the place is too small to accommodate further numbers. An amplification of frontier territory is, therefore, necessary for the security of Spanish interests.

div.head: M. Clemenceau in “Aurore.”
div.p: We have resisted without an effort Ger many's power of seduction. It looked as if Berlin had made np her mind to postpone these manifestations of violent love. Not at all. Now, at the very moment when we seem to be taken back to the early days of the strained situation prevailing at the begin- ning, the“Berliner Tageblatt" seriously suggests that we should ally ourselves with Germany in order to form with Russia a counterpoise to the Anglo-Japanese coalition—that, of course, with the innocent object of restoring the in- dispensable equilibrium for the maintenance of peace among nations.

That is the pretty little lullaby with which William II. went to soothe Nicholas II. at Bjoerkoe. Why should we turn agaist England ? We have no alliance with her, but the fact that England makes common cause with us is just what constitutes Germany's grievance against her. I see clearly that an attempt is being made to frighten us into opposition to England, but, so far as we are concerned, fright cannot take the place of reason. The "Berliner Tageblatt” invokes, it is true, the interest of French Indo-China, the security of which is a matter of concern for us. But to avoid all uneasiness in that direc- tion we need not throw ourselves into the arms of Germany and wage war against the yellow peri]. All we have to do is to seek closer relations with Japan.

div.head: "Republique Francaise.”
div.p: The"Republique Francaise" referring to the recent alerte, says it will have shown Germany the unanimity of the French Press and the perfect harmony of views existing on the subject between the British and French na- tions. It is not without reason that Bebel was able to charge German diplomacy with paving, through its arrogance and its blunders, thrown France into the arms of England. If William II. imagined that by alarming France he would detach her from her entente with the British people he made an egregious error, and every time that there is an opportunity he may realise the effects and the proofs of an increasing intimacy which he, more than anybody else, has contributed to cement during the last few months.

div.head: WHY DELCASSE RESIGNED. “Manchester Guardian.”
div.p: According to Sir Thomas Barclay, when the Morocco trouble with Germany began M. Dalcasse had a project for an alliance with England to which he failed to convert the French Cabinet M. Delcasse, he says, did not resign on pressure from Germany, but because the French Cabinet and he could not agree about the further development to be given to the Anglo-French entente. This is going rather further than the facts, as we know them, would warrant, but Sir Thomas Barclay is undoub- tedly right in the main. M. Delcasse’s fall dealt a deathblow to the idea that out friend- ship with France might become an alliance against Germany. We are well rid of it, for it would be a miserable anti-climax if friendship between two Liberal countries had merely served to provide decrepit Jingoism with stouter crutches. There is no future for our friendship with France except in the advance- ment of Liberal ideas in international affairs. But how glorious that future might be.

div.head: SINKING OF THE CHATHAM. "Evening Standard."
div.p: Rather a curious position has resulted from the sinking of a steamer in the Suez Canal a fortnight ago. The vessel had seventy tons of dynamite on board, and there it a double reason therefore for removing her, if possible, out of the path of navigation. It has now been practically decided that there is only one way of doing this—to blow her up before she has the chance of blowing up anything else. The situation is further complicated by the fact that no one can foretell with exactitude what will be the result of exploding so large a quan- tity of dynamite under such circumstances. Will the vessel shoot up out of the water into the air, like a new kind of Flying Dutchman, or will the disturbance make something like a tidal wave in the Canal!

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton! A la suite delà clôtaro d'Amérique (ta Vendredi dernier, arrivée avec nne vingtaine de points de hausse, nn changement radical est survenn dans l’allure de notre marché : la fai- blesse, qui avait été la note caractéristique de la semaine précédente a fait place h une fer meté remaïqnnblo et à nne amélioration sou daine do 7/S2 sur le Novembre et de 3/16 sur les autres échéances. Il n’en reste cependant pas moins vmi que les plus hauts cours prati- qués depuis lors sont ceux de la matinée de Samedi même, car, à partir du moment où l'on a payé le prix de 14 3/4, un certain désir de réaliser s'est emparé no peu de tous les dé- tenteurs de contrats, ce qui a été cause que pendant toute la semaine nous n'avons fait que îluctuer entre le sus dit maximum et la cote de 14 5/8 affichée à la clôture de ce jour. En somme, notre bilan pour oette huitaine consiste en un bénéfice de 3/32 sur tous les mois, tandis que. l'Amérique, pour sa part, a avancé de 14 points pour les rapprochés, Octobre exclu, jusqu’à 22 points pour les éloignés.

Comme activité nous s avons rien eu de bieu brillant à l’exoeption de la première jonrnér qui a été assez chaude ; le reste du temps les atlsiies ont été en diminuant de jour en jour, au point de friser le calme plat, oomme cela a été ta cas aujourd’hui où, pendant presque une heure entière, la oorteilta est restée déserte on représentée seulement par quelques rares oour- tien et remisiers taillant une bavette en guiso d'occupation. Toutefois, et tout étonnant qu’il soit à oette époque de l’année, oe fait ne nous surprend qu’à moitié, étant donné que l’ex portation est plus que jamais à l'écart des af- faires en oontrats et que, par ta. fait, le marché est toujours complètement abandonné aux que'- ques petits spéculateurs qui sont constamment sur la brèche, mais qui ne peuvent pas faire beauoonp à eux seuls.

Ia filature aussi continue à ce pas s’occuper des futurs et à ne montrer de l'intérêt qae pour la marchandise prête, et même ceh daus une mesure absolument limitée. Anssi, que voyons nous I Une exportation plus que mo- dérée et inférieure à toutes les prévisions (6600 Balles contre 9800 l'année dernière), un marché calme et en baisse de 1/4 de tallari au moins pour les cotons supérieurs Mit-Afifi et cela malgré les artivages,bien petits en comparaison de ceux de 1904 à la même épeque ; seules les provenances Haute-Bgypte, probablement à cause de leur bon marché relatif, ont-, fini soutenues et recherchées, avec une reprise de 1/8 à 1/4 de tallari. Seulement, quand on pense que, à classement égal, l’écart entre oe genre de coton et ta produit de la Basse-Egypte est de 2 1/2 tallari», la chose parait toute na' urello et explique en même temps ta penchant justifié que montrent les acheteurs pour ta genre en question.

Les arrivages ont commencé à avoir l’air de se développer d’une façon normale et, par con- séquent, U nous faudrait un réveil accentué de la demande de la part de la consommation, autrement les pronostios pour la semaine pro- chaine resteraient bien mauvais, vu surtout " qu’elle a à se mettre en ligne avec une expor tation de près de 17000 Balles pour la semaine correspondante de 1904. Il ne faudrait cepen- dant pas être trop pessimiste, attendu que tas besoins existent en Europe et que, si aocalmie il y a, elle ne saurait persister trop longtemps.

Les avis de l’iuttreir sont satislaisants en ce qui conœrne U manière dout on procède dans les villages cette année : ta resserrement du orédit aux petits faiseurs et 1e refus des gros acheteurs d’acheter autrement qu’en fi xant ta prix de suite, ont assaini la situation, oar l'agriculteur, obligé de réaliser à cjqiae de ses besoins pécuniaires, profite malgré lui des prix élevés actuels pour une partie de sa pro- duction, tandis que ta négociant opère aujour d'hui dans des conditions qui écartent pour lui tas ennuis et les a’éas inhérents au ridicule système, qui avait fini par se généraliser, de prendre ta coton contre paiement oomptapt, - mais avec prix à fixer par la suite, ta jour au choix du vendeur, sur des baser déterminées et en se réglant sur les cours des oontrats. Pourvu que l’on persévère dans oette voie 1 !

Quant au rendement à l’égrenage, il s'amé liore de jour en jour; p-^r oontre, un petit point soir à l'horison surgit maintenant : Les noix de 1* troisième eue ! 1st te, dans certaines loca- lités s’ouvreat avant d’arriver à matûrité et, partant, d’auouns commencent à réduire un peu lean estimations. Le mal ne sera certaine- ment pas énorme vu ta peu d’importanoe de notre troisième cueillette, mais eu somme il y a quelque qui oloche ! Les ans signalent le fsit sens pouvoir en expliquer la oauae, tandis que d’autres croient pouvoir l’attribuer à la rotation de JaiUst qui aérait été mal \ comprise ou mal appliquée par le servi oe dee irrigations.
Liverpool a été plutôt iudidéreut à nos oo to ns et les ventes ont été peu importantes, sans changement dans ta prix du spot et avec à peine six points de variation sor la cote do livrable.

Eu Amérique, chacun continue à soutenir C3 qui lui convient et Miss Giles nous vient aujourd'hui avec un rapport de 66 4/10. Ou n’eu fait pourtant pas de oas, car 1e souvenir de son 67 2/10 du mois dernier est encore présent à toutes les mémoires, et, très proba- blement, ni haussiers ni baissiers ne sauraient imprimer au marché une direction quelconque avant le rapport du Bureau d'Agriculture qui doit paraître mardi prochain.

Graines de Coton : Ls disponible, un peu plus abondant sur 1e marché, a faibli, quoique demandé pour nos huileries locales, et fiait aujourd’hui à 55 1/2. La cause 1 Tout simple- ment 1e peu d'empressemsnt de la part de l'exportation et la situation des oontrats.

Ba effet, oette dernière ne s'améliore pas et les affaires à la Bourse sur les 3 mois, restent rares. Au point on uoaa eu sommas, il ne nous resta qu'au seul espoir, o'est une baisse marquée pour attirer les acheteurs, autrement, et comme nous l’avons déjà dit, nous resterons à la meroi de la oonsommati ou du dehors qui n'a oertes pas intérêt à faire la hausse. Eu attendant, la faiblesse domine et les cours reculent, tas 3 mois étant à P.T. 56 25/40.

La baisse dans les huiles et les tourteaux semble s’être arrêtée, oar depiia quelques jours la demaudeest au peu meilleure à Hall. Ou oote £5 6/3 spot Hull vieille marchandise, £ 5 12/6 graine nouvelle Ootobre et £5 12.6 pour les 3 mois.

div.head: SURVEY OF THE SUDAN. INTERVIEW WITH SLATIN PASHA. (Continued from September 26.)
div.p: Taking advantage of a pause in Sir Rudolph R. von Slatin Pasha’s animated and interesting remarks, is asked it he found himself able to detect a genuine progress in civilisation in the Sudan.; — “Yes, certainly I can,’’ he replied. “In the towns you now find better-built houses, and in the villages bigger and cleaner huts. Indi- viduals become more fastidious. Townspeople are already looking for European furniture, and the bulk of the population like nice clothes. But let us give you an example.

“Five years ago I visited the Southern Nuba Mountains. The chief of a big moun- tain, who had never met a white man before came down from his stronghold to see me, because he had beard that I was 'a good man.' He and his followers and wives had very little clothing among them. Beads, brass wire, leather strings round their hips, and some copper ornaments, were the only finery they possessed. I gave this chief similar things as presents, knowing the people wanted them, and I offered him also some small looking- glasses, knives, and a piece of red and yellow coloured cloth. He accepted everything beam ingly, except the cloth. When I explained to him how nice and useful clothing was, he asked me to allow him to express his thoughts freely to me, and, with the assis tance of an interpreter, the following speech was delivered :—

" ‘You know I never wear clothes. My father and grandfather didn’t If it is cold I sit in the sun or near a fire ; if it is warm I sit in the shade. I am healthy and strong You give me these things because you are good. Will this thing last for my whole life If it is finished, from where will I get another Will there be a good man to give it to me for nothing like you do ? Or will he ask me to give him my cow or sheep in exchange ? No, I like the beads and brass wire, because they are nice, but I don’t want your cloth!

“I tried a little to convert this philosopher but gave it op, knowing that in the course o time he would change his opinion. Sum enough, to-day my old friend comes down from his mountain attired briliantly in many coloured garments. Having seen, during the last few years, officers, officials, and soldiers passing continually through his country human nature, old as Adam, began to world in him, and he no longer cared to show himself garbed only in beads and brass wire and so he asked for cloth. The irresistible desire to imitate did more than any words of mine could.

“If you travel now on a steamer along the White Nile, you find the black ladies, who a short time ago, were only clothed in atmo sphere, and the men, who went bare-footed to the neck,' newly all in possession of some clothing -they hesitate to meet you in their former state of nudity. I think this is an ocular demonstration of the progress of civilisation.

“As to whether, by wearing clothes and getting used to luxury, these people will get stronger and healthier, you must not ask me. have not had much medical training, and Id not give them lectures about treatment by natural remedies. But I would be disappointed if a fellow, whom I ordered to meet me said he could not come because yesterday perspiring in full dress, be stood in a draught and caught cold, and was afraid of getting influence, if be moved from his place. But civilisation, on the whole, is a good thing. It gives individuals generally a gentle dis position, and makes them kinder to the neighbours. I cannot say that these are yet the main attributes of our southern Sudan subjects,

“You ask me about missionary work. Mis sionary work is entirely in the hands of private individuals, and the Government ban nothing to do with it But I will explain the situation. We have to divide the Sudan into two zones—the northern and the southern. The northern tone is inhabited by Moslems only. The Sudan Mohamedans arc very igno- rant in religions questions, not civilised enough to, be able to distinguish between the action of a missionary as a single private individual and the action of Government. It would be very dangerous to adopt so liberal and tolerant a policy as obtains in Egypt. I think the greater part of the Sudan Moha- medans world believe that the Government was trying to make them Christians, and would became irritated. Therefore, the time is still distant when missionary work should Im allowed amongst the Moslems of the Sudan.

“Of course, there are missionary schools at Khartoum for children of Christian residents, with strict regulations, and there are not a few Mohamedans who send their children to be educated in these schools. But these schools are at the seat of a watchful Government, and every Mohamedan knows through Govern- ment the conditions under which instruction is given before sending his child to school. He understands thoroughly that such schools are not to make proselytes, but only for general education.

“Quite different are the conditions in the southern zone. There the population consists only of pagans. Except some tribes on the White Nile, near Shambe and Gondokoro, and some of the Nuba mountains where Roman Catholic missionary stations were established in former days, those savages have not been brought into contact with any Christians. They know the Mohamedana only slave raiders, and were nearly annihilated by them under the Dervish rule. This is the part of the Sudan for missionary work. Spheres of action for the different missionary Societies have been defined. American missionaries are active on the Sobat and south-east. The Roman Catholic mission has its headquarters at 'Lull (south of Kodok, formerly Fashoda) and has also several stations at Tonga in the Bahr el Ghazel Only the British Missionary Society has not yet began its work.

“Of course, the work of the missionaries has to be at the beginning only a civilising one. If the missionaries should attempt to intro- duce Christianity at once, and offer a wealthy native to send his wives away because only one is allowed—they would soon be left alone and well treated. But; through sound advice as to how to improve their wealth, technical instruction, and tactful appealing to their common-sense, and offering assistance in little matters, the missionaries will become popular and will gain influence. The Bishop Mon- signor Dr. Geyer, the head of the Catholic mission, is most energetic and active, and when I last met him, just returned from an inspection, he expressed his- thorough satis- faction with the situation and the behaviour of the natives. Ha said he had not baptised any yet, and he bad not yet any Chris- tian converts, but he had already improved the character of the population inhanding bis different stations. This southern part of the Sudan is, of course, also open to Mohamedans, but no application has been made till now by private individuals to establish schools where the religion of Islam would be taught or general instruction given.

And as to slavery. There is no more slave raiding on a big scale. There was only one man, Ibrahim Wad Mahmood, near the Abys- sinian frontier, who, living on an almost in- accessible mountain, raided the pagan tribes of his neighbourhood. He was defeated by Colonel Gorringe, late Mudir of Sennar, and hanged. The greater part of his followers were killed. There may be a raid or two in miniature in a far-away district, but these must be regarded more as tribal quarrels than as raids for the purpose of making slaves, There have been a few cases of kidnapping, but the different posts of the Slavery Depart- ment are practically patrolling the roads, There is not much chance of any such male- factors escaping the eagle eyes of those officials, and passing with slaves through the Sudan.

“Governors of provinces are working hand- in-hand with the Slavery Department, of which Captain McMurdo is the head, and they have stated that there is no doubt that the slave trade in the Sudan has received a very severe check, and that only isolated cases now occur. During my continual travelling I make careful in- quiries on this subject, and I am glad to be able to say that the traffic in human beings has practically ceased. After the reconquest of the Sudan, freedom was declared. It was in some ways hard on the population. They were accustomed to keep slaves, and it was allowed by their law and religion—and no compensation was given to them for the loss of their slaves.

“Not a few landowners were unable to cul- tivate their estates, as at the beginning of the new regime all blacks tried to enjoy their freedom thoroughly, and it was not easy for us to keep such a mass of loafers in order. But it could not be helped, and the Mohamedan natives understand our rea sons.

“Through the registration of all individuals of pagan extraction in the Mohamedan Sudan we are now able to control their movements. The black is by nature a lazy individual, who does not like to be supervised. But with the advance of civilisation, he knows now the value and necessity of money, and realises that he cannot get it for nothing. Hence, with the agreement and assistance of the Arab population, we are gradually changing the statue of slavery into a system of paid labour, which will be liked by both master and servant"
In reply to a question regarding the fron- tier between the Congo Free State and the Sudan, the Inspector-General said :—

“Well, that is a very delicate question, and a soldier cannot say much about matters which are in the hands of diplomatists. But to speak generally, it is a great mistake to limit a frontier by degrees of latitude or lon- gitude. It is quite easy to say the country north or south or east or west of such a degree belongs to this or that nation. It looks neat and nice on a map. But what has the poor fellow to do who is living on or near such an artificial frontier, and whose watering and razing places are beyond the official limit of his country ? If he passes the imaginary line, which he is, perhaps, bound to do for his existence, he is driven back by force, or has to pay heavily for his trespass.

You must understand that many tribes- men are in the habit of changing their grazing grounds and cultivations during the year, without being nomads. The frontiers between tribes in Africa—and, I think, elsewhere too— have been settled by fighting in the course of ages. It has been a struggle for existence. Now we come and say, ‘North of this degree you belong to me, south to somebody else.’ Tbe tribe, perhaps, is quite willing to belong to you altogether, but declines to be cut in two. Then it brings endless trouble for the administration, too. A discontented individual or a malefactor has only to go over the frontier, and can there hide himself among his relatives, who are able to protect him, as he belongs to another Government He would not easily find an asylum with another tribe.

Therefore, every Government should try to have always first a political frontier, if pos- sible. The geographical comes only in second line. In this special case, I do not think the Chief of the Congo Free State is thoroughly informed about the situation. The Free State Government sticks to its right that the fifth degree should be the limit but if the fifth degree of latitude is to be considered as a frontier, the Congo State will find great diffi- culty in administering this part of the country, as a sub-section of the Niam-Niam will be cut in two whereas, if we have the watershed as frontier, things would be much easier. On the whole, I do not think the country is worth1 quarrelling about There is not much to gain; and some indiarubber trees and a few villages, which are scarcely populated, will not make much difference to either Government The matter is more a question of conveniance to the few subjects living there. With regard to our other frontiers, the French Sudan, Uganda, Abyssinia, and Eritreg, there reigns ’the entente cordiale'."

“You ask about our medical arrangements. We are short of doctors. At Khartoum we have a thorough modern civil hospital, under Dr. Christopher son, who, through his kindness and ability, has gained the confidence of the popu- lation. We have also is all provinces hospitals, but at the out-stations civil work is still super vised by British medical officers, and we feel the dearth of native doctors—I mean Egyptians or Syrians—as Sudanese are only quack doc- tors, or medicine men.

“You ask me about the army. As to the indefatigable work of the Sirdar, his adjutant- general, and officers, the army is equal to any European. The equipment of the different arms is up to data, and the discipline and power of maneuvering is excellent. One British regiment is always at Khartoum The Egyptian battalions are stationed at Khartoum and dis- tricts north of it. The Sudanese battalions are posted in the southern provinces. This arrange- ment is trade for sanitary reasons. The army at the present strength is sufficient to meet any eventuality, but I hope, for the sake of the country, that there will be no necessity to demonstrate its value.

"Finally, with regard to myself. There is not much to say. I am still travelling over the Sudan—sometimes comfortably, sometimes roughing it. My position forces me to put my finger into every one’s pie, and if my com- radee may be occasionally bored by my advice, I am sore they are convinced of my good intentions. I confess I should like to enjoy a little more civilisation, instead of living the greater part of the year with half or thorough savages ; but as the Government still desires my services, and has declined my resignation, I am ready to help as much as I can to improve the situation in the Sudan as long as my health stands fit. Then, too, when all is said, life is short I am old to change my metier, and I am very closely identified with Africa. I make no particular pretensions to modesty. __

" I have a wide and intimate local know- ledge of the country and its inhabitants, and I have the thorough cobfidence of the different tribes. Therefore, I am able to render valuable services to the Government.
“ The conviction that I am of use to the country, and that my advice is appreciated by the Government and the natives,—that is my reward and my satisfaction.’’
And so ended what the Inspector-General described as the longest “interview" he had ever experienced.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY. ( From our Correspondent ). London, September 20.
div.p: Colonel T. L N. Morland, C.B., D.S.O., who has been appointed Inspector-General of the West African Frontier Force, in succession to Brigadier General Kemball, is well-known on the West Coast as he has been employed with the W.A.F.F. for the past seven and a half years and was latterly commandant of the forces in Nigeria. His record of active service is a good one including the operations up the Niger, 1897 98 (mentioned in despatches, medal with clasp), the operations in Northern Nigeria, 1900, when he commanded on Kanduma River ; (mentioned in despatches), the Ashanti Expedition of the same year (mentioned in despatches, brevet lieutenant-colonelcy) ; com- manded the troops in the campaign against the Emir of Yola, 1900, when he was slightly wounded in action (mentioned in despatches, D.SO, medal with clasp commanded the troops in the Bornu Expedition, 1903 (men- tioned in despatches), and his last service was in the Kano-Sokoto Expedition, 1903, when his services were recognised by a well-earned CB.

Captain W. P. Bassett, Rifle Brigade, who has just been promoted to the rank in the adjutant of the 3rd Battalion at Khartoom. He reaches that rank after a little less than six year’s service. Captain M. H. Helyar, simil- arly promoted after the same length of service is with the 3rd Battalion at Aden.

In addition to Royal Artillery and Royal Engineer drafts the following drafts will embark on the S.S. Duners, at Southampton, on the 87th inrt. for Egypt — Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers 149 non-commissioned officers and men for the 2nd Battalion at Cairo; under Captain 0. H. Collins, D.8.O., and Lieutenant 0. W. Hemp, Royal Berkshire Regiment; and Second Lieutenant W. P. B. Frazer of the Inniskillings ; Royal Berkshire Regiment, 160 non-commissioned officers and men under Second Lieutenants B. T. W. M'Causland, M. C. Radford and A. G. M. Sharpe, for the 3nd Battalion at Alexandria ; Royal Dublin Fusiliers, 150 non-commissioned officers and men under Lieutenant Broadhurst-Hills, for the 1st Battalion which is ordered from Malta to Cairo. Major Feetham, Royal Berks Regi- ment, will be in command of the troops on board the Dunera.

According to a return up to the let Septem- ber the number of British officers employed with the Egyptian Army is 169 of all racks. The Foot Guards, infantry of the Royal Marines, and West India Regiment supply the great majority — about one hundred—the Royal Engineers supply 19, the R.A.M.O., 19; Royal Artillery, 10 ; Cavalry 6, and the ba- lance by departmental corps.
Poor Tommy Atkins will have to bear with the hated Brodriok for a little season, as it seems that a general issue of the new walking out cap will not be made for some time.

The gunboat Thrush, which after her return last year from the West African Coast was pot on the sale list, is to get a new lease of life as a tender. Perhaps the feet that the Thrush was the first command of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales on the North America Station may account for her re-habilitation.
